name: Clin N Merkel Cell Penis
title: Clinical N
notes:
**Note 1:**  Code only regional nodes and nodes, NOS, in this field.  Distant nodes are coded in distant metastasis.

**Note 2:**  Bilateral nodes are considered regional nodes for tumors with bidirectional drainage to primary nodal basins, as shown on lymphoscintigraphy.  Clinical assessment of bilateral regional nodal involvement is required for tumors where lymphoscintigraphy is not performed.

**Note 3:**  Contiguous or secondary nodal basins are the next nodal drainage basins beyond the primary nodal basins.  Secondary basins are considered regional for TNM staging. 

**Note 4:**  In transit metastasis is defined as a tumor distinct from the primary lesion and located either between the primary lesion and the draining regional lymph nodes or distal to the primary lesion. In transit metastasis is coded in regional lymph nodes.

**Regional lymph nodes:**

    Isolated tumor cells (ITCs) only
    SINGLE superficial inguinal (femoral) regional lymph node
    SINGLE inguinal node, NOS (unknown if superficial or deep)
    MULTIPLE or BILATERAL superficial inguinal (femoral) regional lymph nodes
    MULTIPLE or BILATERAL inguinal nodes, NOS (unknown if superficial or deep)

    Deep inguinal, NOS:
        Node of Cloquet or Rosenmuller (highest deep inguinal)
    Pelvic lymph nodes (unilateral or bilateral):
       External iliac
       Internal iliac (hypogastric):
        Obturator
    Pelvic nodes in contiguous or secondary nodal basin 
    Pelvic nodes, NOS
rows: Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed

Unknown; regional lymph nodes not stated
Not documented in patient record

Regional lymph nodes, NOS
Lymph nodes, NOS

Stated as N1

Clinically apparent in-transit metastasis WITH or WITHOUT occult nodal metastasis

Clinically apparent in-transit metastasis and clinically apparent nodal metastasis 

Stated as N2
